title: 106_hr2643
content: Ownership. Repeal of Ownership Based on Aboriginal Lands and Inadvertent Discovery amendments to the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act include changes to ownership provisions and requirements for disposing of cultural items on Federal lands. Cultural items excavated or discovered on Federal lands after November 16, 1990, must be recorded according to scientific standards and remain under agency control for 90 days. Cultural items excavated on Federal lands after November 16, 1990, must be recorded and remain under agency control for 90 days after publication in the Federal Register. Limited authorization for study is granted by amending the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act. The last sentence of a specific section is modified to include exceptions outlined in other sections. The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act is amended to allow for studies to establish cultural affiliation of items. Federal agencies or museums must notify culturally affiliated tribes or organizations within 90 days of such determination. The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act allows for studies to establish cultural affiliation of items. If a cultural item is affiliated with an Indian tribe or Native Hawaiian organization, studies may be conducted for scientific research. The item must be returned to the tribe or organization within 90 days if requested after the study is completed. The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act allows for studies to establish cultural affiliation of items. A cultural item must be returned within 180 days after study completion, unless a longer period is agreed upon by the tribe or organization. The Federal agency or museum must provide a report of the study results to the affiliated tribe or organization within 180 days. The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act allows for studies on cultural items, with the custody holder required to make the item available for study unless outweighed by curatorial, cultural, or other considerations. Museums are not obligated to permit studies conflicting with their policies or agreements.
